summary:
Maarten Smies is a highly and widely experienced environmental (and HSE and CSR) management advisor with twenty years of direct experience in the exploration and production of oil and gas business and nine years of earlier environmental experience.  Until his retirement in 2008 he was EP Global Environment Lead with Shell International Exploration & Production.  He has carried out substantial in-country projects in Nigeria, Gabon, Tanzania, Zaire/Congo, the USA, Canada, Colombia, the UAE, India, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Australia, Russia and Kazakhstan and completed senior postings to Oman, the UAE and Iran.  In addition, he has had considerable involvement in communication and the environmental/communication interface and engagement in sustainable development and in learning and development in environmental and CSR management.  

Maarten is a co-founder (with Eva Kimonye from Kenya) of YoungProfsNet of environmental and social development practitioners, an international on-line platform for mutual and cooperative learning and development by and for young professionals: http://youngprofsnet.org/

An all-round environmental, HSE and CSR management advisor, Maarten has extensive intercultural experience and is a good team player and a motivating leader of staff.  

Maarten has been engaged in substantial activities and responsibilities in his professional field and in the corporate social responsibility (CSR) field.  He has been a board member for eight years and vice-president of the Dutch National Trust for Nature Conservation and is a recognised leader there.  Recently, he was CSR advisor to PUM – Netherlands senior experts. 

Since June 2015 Maarten is a co-founder and the managing director of YoungProfsNet of environmental and social development practitioners. 



Specialties: Environmental management and consultancy; Sustainable Development and (Corporate) Social Responsibility management and consultancy.

projects.title: Waste Management and Best Available Technology
projects.description:
Waste management is historically based on the “3R” hierarchy (reduce, re-use, recycle).  Some companies have successfully run long-lasting waste reduction programs.  Integrated waste management is a more comprehensive approach aimed at saving resources (materials, water, energy) and at reducing capital and labor costs.  
Re-use and recycling of waste has turned into a substantial economic sector and provides a number of important environmental benefits.  
Best Available Technologies for industrial processes and the management of wastes from these provide yardsticks for economic, technological and environmental performance.  Information on these technologies is publicly available.  Regulatory agencies may use them for approving permits to industry.

projects.description:
I advised a Mongolian environmental consultancy on the merits and demerits of standard management systems in relation to business development.  We also exchanged experience and information on Impact Assessment of industrial projects.  

We are now in the follow-up stage of this project and an earlier project of PUM with this consulting company on technical expertise and professional competency of staff.  The company will develop an implementation plan with regard to the recommendations made for the two projects.  In addition, the client will work on a business development plan to realise its growth ambitions, for which PUM is prepared to serve as an advisor.

projects.title: Environmental and sustainability certification for the hotel industry
projects.description: Environmental certification schemes for the hotel industry generally do not require hotels to adopt a formal environmental management system.  By contrast, sustainability certification schemes tend to be built around a formal sustainability management system.  While it is clear that sustainability management is more comprehensive than environmental management, sustainability may be achieved more simply than required by the formal sustainability certification schemes available.

projects.title: Environmental Management System for hotels in Ukraine
projects.description:
In 2009, Green Dossier, an information and publishing centre in Ukraine, requested the assistance of an expert in environmental matters. Green Dossier’s main goal is to educate people, especially youth, by providing knowledge in humanities, environmental issues and sustainable development. 
The centre was working on an Environmental Management System (EMS) and certification scheme for (small and medium size) enterprises, especially small and medium size hotels, in Ukraine. Together with the Green Dossier staff involved, the expert conducted a comprehensive review of the draft EMS.  This resulted in a shift in focus to make the management system more attractive to the hotel trade by highlighting the potential economic and business benefits of joining the scheme.  To test these ideas, Green Dossier staff and the expert interviewed the management of three small hotels in different parts of Ukraine.  
The expert also provided advice on the certification procedure, exploring different models.  And he gave guidance on a possible business plan to set up a consultancy on EMS and EMS certification.  
Quote of the expert after his mission: ‘I was delighted to be asked to help develop an Environmental Management System and a certification scheme for hotels in Ukraine. Hotels can make great steps in improving their environmental performance and by doing so improve their financial performance as well’. 
Three years later, the system is up and running.  Until now EMS certificates have been awarded to five hotels, of which three achieved the highest grade (of three).

volunteer_experiences.description:
AVN is a 90-year old lobby organisation for nature conservation interests in The Hague and its environs.  AVN aims to influence municipal policy on green issues as well as provincial nature and landscape planning around The Hague.  We also provide specialist support on conservation issues in the different areas of The Hague in relation to municipal policy and practice and in support of community initiatives.  

In 2012 AVN organised a symposium on the future of Green Belts around The Hague, that the Dutch national government established in the 1950s but withdrew its protection in 2011.  The symposium explored options for sustainable protection by the Province of South-Holland and the relevant municipal administrations to preserve these Green Belts.  

In 2014 AVN organised a symposium on Biodiversity in the city, which provided significant input for the review of the Municipality of The Hague's Green Policy Plan in 2015.
